John Nash.Action: Nash overhears conversation but remains quietly observant, does not engage directly to compete or insult.
Responds to Milnor's sarcastic comment by correcting him calmly and nodding slightly before walking away.
Does not retaliate or escalate the mild social slight when mistaken for a waiter and insulted about his clothes.
Stares in wonder at Charles Herman's antics but remains silent and reserved.
Moves desk in front of window and marks players' positions in a game, indicating engagement and shared activity with Charles.
Continues working quietly as Charles unpacks and talks, showing tolerance and acceptance of Charles' behavior.
Marks player positions on the window pane using wax boxes and vectors to analyze a football game.
Speechless and stunned when meeting his unruly and disruptive roommate Charles Herman.
Covers bowl of cookies to prevent sharing, doesn't look up from work.
Shrugs off roommate's teasing and describes himself as not warm and not good with people.
Reaches into his pocket, pulls out two wrapped amaretto cookies, and offers one to Charles.
Finally smiles back at Charles after receiving the cookie comment.
Smiles after being teased by Milnor.
Refuses to join the game group, saying 'Classes dull the mind and destroy authentic creativity. No offense.'
Engages in fast-paced GO game with Milnor, maintaining eye contact and focused interaction.
Dismisses others' work as 'adequate' or 'derivative drivel.'
Rides bicycle in figure eights with eyes half-closed, causing students to scatter.
Walks backwards while whistling Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata, appearing confident and distinctive.
Dismisses traditional classes as dull and stifling creativity, expressing an independent mindset.
Plays GO at a high speed against Milnor, maintaining strong focus and skill.
Critiques others’ work as 'adequate' or 'derivative', showing confidence in his own higher standards.
Smiles after Milnor accuses him of being scared and lacking nerve to compete.
Sits stunned and furious after losing a game, then sweeps the board and walks away.
Shows no response to Milnor’s taunting questions, concentrating inwardly rather than engaging.
Walks alone staring at the GO board deep in frustration, isolated and withdrawn.
Interrupts an ongoing game abruptly, causing disruption and fear by pulling a knife and slicing the board.
Concentrates silently on the game despite provocation and an implied challenge.
Refuses to acknowledge losing the game and claims the game is flawed after defeat.
Displays frustration but continues to engage with the problem deeply, staring at the GO board for an extended time, indicating introspection and persistence.
Abruptly interrupts a game by grabbing the board mid-play, scattering pieces and wielding a knife with a manic gleam in his eyes.
Cuts the GO board into a triangle efficiently with two deft strokes, demonstrating skillfulness in his unorthodox act.
Turns and walks away after cutting the board into a triangle, ignoring others around him.
Draws game scenarios on the library window and shares interpretations with Charles, showing a thoughtful, sincere side.
Cuts the board into a triangle and invents a new game variant that impresses by its perfect properties.
Feels exhausted and reports to Charles that despite efforts he has come up with nothing new yet on his research.
Explains his visualized patterns on the window with insightful understanding of competitive behavior.
Expresses desire and insight about devising a strategy where nobody loses, showing innovative and strategic thinking.
Follows Charles after he playfully mentions pizza and beer despite initial confusion.
Acts puzzled but accepts a beer offered by a friend without hesitation.
Approaches a woman at the bar after being signaled, but does so warily and clinically appraises her, leading to awkward silence.
Makes a bank shot at the pool table and chalks up again.
Takes a beer handed to him but appears puzzled.
Appraises a woman clinically before deciding how to respond.
Stares blankly when asked when he last ate.
Engages people socially at the bar despite awkwardness.
Uses clinical, blunt language to ask for sex, lacking social tact.
Fails to engage in friendly social rituals like buying drinks or smiling when advised, showing social cluelessness.
Says 'I don't make friends' and calls himself an asshole seriously, indicating social withdrawal.
Speaks with deliberate, rapid words showing intellectual sharpness.
Attempts to negotiate sexual interest with overly clinical and awkward phrasing.
Questions social etiquette and seems unaware of emotional social cues despite being a genius.
Responds with dry humor and self-awareness about his social shortcomings.
Expresses a clear preference for RAND as his first-choice placement during academic placement discussions.
Shows social isolation by stating 'I don't make friends' and seeming disconnected from colleagues.
Stares blankly at Van Neumann after a serious, almost personal conversation; does not respond emotionally or appreciatively to Van Neumann's attempt at warmth or empathy.
Cracks his head hard against the glass in frustration and despair, showing internal suffering but no reach for comfort or connection.
Pleading eyes full of rage and anguish; expresses inability to fail with desperation; smashes head into glass repeatedly.
After receiving comfort from Charles, shows a small comfort and begins to follow advice modestly.
Shares a shocked grin with Charles after the desk crashes through the window, showing a moment of connection and lightness.
Pledges 'I can’t fail' and shows fierce determination despite despair.
Slams his head into the glass repeatedly, showing self-destructive behavior.
Eventually accepts some comfort and begins to take action by pulling the desk away and resolving to engage with classes and books.
Allows himself to be pushed into breaking the window with the desk, demonstrating impulsiveness and emotional outburst.
Sits alone, silently observing the group and the interaction with the women rather than engaging or showing sociable behavior.
Does not respond to taunts or engage in competitive banter with friends about the women, remaining quietly focused.
Remains silent and focused, not reacting to social taunts, demonstrating confidence and self-possession.
Critiques a common economic theory (Adam Smith) thoughtfully in a social setting, showing intellectual engagement.
Sits alone, staring at the floor instead of engaging with others in a social setting.
Proposes cooperation to avoid blocking and insulting each other to achieve a collective good outcome
Dismisses Adam Smith's purely self-interested view in favor of mutual benefit for self and group
Smiles when addressed by General, acknowledges the situation with a simple 'constantly.'
Silences the officer politely by raising his hand, focusing intently on the problem.
Engages others by instructing and marking the map, sharing his insights clearly.
Glances at the glass booth and questions who is watching, showing curiosity.
Asks 'What are the Russians moving, General?' indicating concern and involvement with others' efforts.
Focuses deeply on code and problem-solving, showing little explicit social engagement beyond necessary interactions.

Silences the officer, intently studies complex code for hours, whistles thoughtfully while analyzing patterns, accurately identifies routing orders and geographic references, confidently directs others to bring a map, and interprets intercepted Russian transmissions.
Asks 'Who’s Big Brother?' noticing a mysterious observer, showing awareness and curiosity.
Engages in casual banter with Fox and Zweifel, showing camaraderie despite the serious setting.
Dismisses serious military matters by joking and stripping down to his t-shirt in the office, showing a sense of ease and informality around colleagues.
Makes a sarcastic remark to Fox ('How about you blow me?'), demonstrating a teasing but potentially abrasive style of interaction.
Engages with military personnel and colleagues confidently, discusses classified information and assignments with ease and wit, navigates complex environments like RAND headquarters skillfully.
Complains about air conditioning and expresses frustration about trivial issues like discomfort while working on serious assignments.
Recognizes and questions the mismatch between the team’s assignments (stress tests for a dam) and the actual geopolitical threats (Soviet H-bomb), implying strategic insight.
Makes the cover of Forbes as one of America's geniuses, showing recognized intellectual achievement.
Expresses irritation and possessiveness about being recognized alone as a genius, indicating confidence and self-assurance.
Tries to get a note from a doctor to skip class, showing attempt to avoid responsibility but does so unsuccessfully.
Responds firmly and confidently to noise disruptions by closing windows and asserting his priorities in class.
Dismissively tells students their comfort comes second to his teaching ability and calls the class a waste of time, showing bluntness but also possible alienation of students.
Offers the barest nod to Alicia after her disruptive action, then turns back to the board without engaging her or showing any acknowledgment beyond minimal recognition.
Nods politely and quietly when William Parcher praises him and discusses serious moral consequences, showing a reserved, solemn acknowledgment.
Dismisses the class dismissively, asserting control over the situation and setting a challenging equation for students, demonstrating confidence and intellectual skill.
Responds calmly and subtly to Alicia’s unexpected disruptive behavior in class by offering a bare nod and returning to his work without losing composure.
Nods in acknowledgment of Parcher’s government credentials and military background without obvious unease, suggesting confidence and ease in high-stakes or authoritative interactions.
Expresses knowledge and reverence about historical scientific figures and projects, indicating intellectual competence and awareness.
Displays a momentary sign of awe (eyes widening) when hearing about the atomic project, revealing human vulnerability but no clear incompetence.
Falls into step with Parcher and engages with him during the walk.
Responds to Parcher’s question 'No close friends. No family. Why is that, John?' with 'Get to know me.'
Makes a casual, approving comment 'Good speech.' to Parcher’s serious monologue.
Signs a top-secret form without hesitation to assist in a critical national security operation.
Expresses concern about potential civilian casualties and the gravity of the threat.
Engages seriously and sincerely in a conversation about potentially catastrophic consequences.
Signs the Top Secret security clearance form without hesitation and immediately engages with Parcher to understand the details of a highly sensitive and complex operation.
Listens attentively to critical intelligence about a hidden nuclear threat and asks relevant, focused questions about the operation’s nature, target, and consequences.
Expresses concern and comprehends the gravity of the situation quickly, indicating awareness and insight.
Nash agrees to help by stating, 'Tell me what you want me to do.'
Nash silently complies with the implantation of the radium diode and memorization of codes without protest.
Nash appears isolated, told to avoid new people and assume he is being watched, standing alone in the courtyard.
Nash agrees to memorize complex codes and scan periodicals for hidden messages, demonstrating his ability to handle difficult cognitive tasks.
Nash calmly accepts the implantation of a radium diode under his skin as part of his spy work, showing adaptability and composure.
Nash asks straightforward questions such as 'In the U.S.?' and 'So what am I now? A spy?' indicating critical thinking and some skepticism.
Tells the soldier escort 'It’s all right, Mike,' allowing him to leave politely.
Subtly corrects Alicia's work but compliments her second proof as elegant.
Responds bluntly and seemingly dismissively at times, e.g., 'No. You didn’t.' and barely glances at her paper.
Invites Alicia to dinner after some hesitation and appears quietly receptive.
Returns to work immediately after agreeing on dinner, showing minimal social engagement.
Correctly dismisses Alicia when she asks to be dismissed, then calls her back before she leaves, showing attentiveness.
Introduces Alicia warmly to the Governor at the party.
Seems distracted and avoids engaging fully with Alicia's comments, focusing instead on two men across the room.
Responds minimally ('Um-hmm') to Alicia's personal revelations without evident emotional engagement.
Nash follows the men with his eyes instead of paying attention to Alicia, indicating social detachment.
After Alicia’s physical prompt (kicking him), Nash acknowledges her and nods, showing eventual recognition of her attempt to connect.
Calmly dismisses Alicia but then remembers to call her back for 'one more thing,' showing social awareness and a measured control of the situation.
Presents Alicia to the Governor at a formal event confidently and appropriately.
Distractedly watches two men at the bar during a conversation, indicating lack of focus on social interaction.
Fails to immediately engage with Alicia's statements, only vaguely responding without real attention.
Responds suitably after Alicia kicks him to get his attention and then acknowledges her with a nod.
Offers Alicia a glass of champagne and stands next to her, sharing a quiet moment together.

Looks startled and reluctant to confront the men who are staring at him.
Engages in a gentle, imaginative conversation with Alicia about choosing shapes in the stars, showing a moment of intimacy and connection.
Quietly carries champagne and supports Alicia socially, but avoids engaging directly with the men who are staring at him.
Nods knowingly in response to Alicia's comment about his fame, indicating self-awareness and social cognition.
Hesitates and appears unconvinced when asked about technology stocks, showing caution or critical thinking in unfamiliar territory.
Looks startled and reluctant to interact with the two men who keep staring at him, suggesting social discomfort or avoidance.
Points out complex patterns in the stars to Alicia, creating imagery like an umbrella and an octopus, demonstrating imagination and attention to detail.
Surrounds himself with magazines and research materials at home, appearing deeply immersed in his work despite missing conferences and briefings.
Misses important professional meetings and fails to communicate effectively with colleagues who express concern.
Deflects questions about his absence or progress with vague responses like 'It's classified,' avoiding transparency.

Raises his hand to stop further conversation, indicating self-control and focus on his work.
Resumes working alone after Fox leaves, showing dedication and concentration.
Engages in meticulous organization of torn pages and maps, culminating in a carefully sealed RAND envelope.
Uses a secret code appearing on his wrist to access a keypad and deliver the envelope securely.

Locks gates behind him, runs to car and locks doors quickly after hearing rustling; appears fearful and withdrawn.
Engages in playful competition with Alicia during swimming; allows natural interaction.

Admits he is not good with people and tends to be very direct, which often results in poor social outcomes.

Tells Alicia to wait while he cleans up his workspace, showing some regard for order but also a slight insistence on control.
Allows Alicia to initiate undressing and responds by going to her, suggesting a reciprocal and engaging intimate moment.
Acknowledges his weakness in social skills but understands his own behavior and communicates directly about it.
Uses logical, analytical approach to human interaction, applying it to personal relationships, demonstrating self-awareness and intellectual rigor.
Despite his awkwardness, successfully initiates intimacy with Alicia, showing some confident social navigation in a difficult area for him.
Hastily cleans up his work materials when noticing potential surveillance, showing caution and situational awareness.
His focus on work leads to neglect of order; magazines and papers scattered on surfaces and floor indicate occasional disorganization.

Appears confused or unsure when asked if he knows Marcee.
Suffers from nightmares and is distressed upon waking, showing vulnerability but not indicating incompetence.

Withdraws emotionally from Alicia and isolates himself by locking his study door and not responding.

In class, delivers a final exam early, dismissing participation and abruptly exits the room, leaving students confused.
Hurries away from footsteps, too tired to notice Alicia's surprise lunch plan, shows signs of distraction and weariness.

Expresses vulnerability and fear of paranoia openly to William, asking for protection for himself and family.

Ignores Fox’s concern and does not respond to a friendly inquiry.
Orders Alicia to turn off the light abruptly, scares the infant by slamming his hand, and destroys her painting in frustration.
Turns to face his wife and wailing child despite his distress and paranoia.
Refuses to quit working despite pressure and threats from Parcher, showing commitment to his work.
Shouts and acts erratically in his own apartment, knocking over furniture and throwing a canvas, showing signs of distress and losing control.
Carefully observes outside through the window before dropping the blind, showing cautiousness and awareness of potential danger.
Explodes and orders Alicia to leave immediately, slamming the door and rocking himself.
Lifts Marcee up and hugs her tightly, closing his eyes affectionately.
Smiles weakly when greeted and admits he needs help.
Explodes in anger, slams the door, refuses to communicate calmly with his wife.
Climbs the steps of the Mathematics building despite appearing disheveled and anxious, checking over his shoulder.
Acknowledges Marcee’s greeting, shows emotional connection.
Admits he is 'into something' and needs help.
Hesitates to share details about his situation, stops speaking just as he is about to explain.
Offers a charming smile before resisting arrest.

Politely asks for an exit when confused during lecture.
Calls out for help loudly, appealing to bystanders and friends.

Recognizes Rosen and calls out to Charles and Marcee, showing awareness of his environment.
Attempts to sit up despite being bound and under medication.
Shoves Rosen onto the floor in an aggressive response while restrained and medicated.
Pleading with hallucinated friends to respond and show recognition, showing desperate need for connection.
Growing hysterical and angry when ignored by imagined figures, indicating emotional vulnerability and sincere yearning for interaction.
Refusing to accept reality and lashing out in frustration towards caregivers, showing distrust and emotional turmoil.
Shoves Rosen onto the floor in an attempt to resist or fight back.
Attempts to escape by trying for the door despite having restraints on his ankles.

Grows hysterical and unable to accept the reality or follow directions from Rosen and orderlies.
Shows signs of confusion and impaired situational awareness (talking to hallucinations, unable to recognize his environment accurately).
Mumbling and rocking in a cell, clearly suffering from schizophrenia, showing vulnerability but no interaction here.
Lost the ability to distinguish between reality and imagination, experiences hallucinations and paranoia, showing impaired judgment.
Believes in elaborate fantasies such as government espionage and imaginary acquaintances, showing detachment from reality.
Maintains a classified work profile and mentions contacts like William Parcher, indicating ongoing intellectual engagement despite mental struggles.
Stands silently at the window, watching Alicia leave under the moon, showing no outward expression or interaction.
Stands at the window, quietly observing his surroundings despite being committed.
Behaves strangely at work, causing discomfort to colleagues.
Keeps secretive work that isolates him from others.

Appears deeply distrustful, accusing Rosen of conspiracy and brainwashing attempts.
Walks thoughtfully to abandoned warehouses and spends time thinking to himself.

Expresses strong delusions about conspiracies and believes Rosen is trying to brainwash him.
Stumbles briefly when confronted but quickly recovers composure.
Refuses to engage Rosen's probing questions and avoids confronting his own mental state.
Knocks away Rosen’s hand firmly and challenges medical intervention, showing mental strength and assertiveness.
Expresses anger and frustration but remains aware enough to confront Rosen and the Orderly with confidence.
Shows confusion and darkness of expression when told treatment depends on his cooperation, revealing vulnerability.
Allows Alicia to hold his hands despite being in distress; acknowledges and comforts her by saying 'It’s going to be all right.'
Initially mistakes Alicia for one of the patients, lacks immediate trust.
Speaks quietly about a shared concern to protect Alicia, showing consideration for her safety.
Wipes important documents angrily onto the floor, indicating frustration and emotional instability rather than warmth.
Sits staring at Princeton documents but then angrily wipes them to the floor, showing frustration but also a moment of resolve.

Sits calmly in the common room among other patients, maintaining composure while interacting quietly and thoughtfully with Alicia, indicating some mental confidence and intelligence despite circumstances.
Warns Alicia quietly about possible surveillance, showing awareness and cautious strategic thinking.
Begins to confide deeply and urgently in Alicia, asking for her help.
Insists on the reality of his secret work despite Alicia's distress and protests.
Reacts emotionally to Alicia's breaking of the illusion, appearing hurt and vulnerable.
Insists on the existence of a government conspiracy and secret work despite evidence to the contrary.
Keeps sealed envelopes with code and maps never picked up or opened, believing they are part of his secret work.
Attempts to convey urgent, important information and enlist help, showing confidence and determination.
Cries and shows visible fear and pain while injured and restrained.
Denies existence of an implant while severely injured, possibly trying to protect others or maintain trust.
Gouges his own wrist trying to remove a nonexistent implant, denies presence of anything there despite obvious wound.
Crying and showing fear while restrained in the mental hospital, confused about reality.
Endures painful insulin shock treatment and is in remission after difficult treatments.
Terminated from government contract due to mental illness, implying professional setbacks.
Nash gestures to an empty porch swing, inviting Fox to sit, indicating a desire for companionship.
Jokes about his mental state to lighten the mood: 'Relax. What good's being nuts if you can‘t have a little fun?'
Replies to Fox somewhat curtly, 'Finally. A little respect.' showing irritation.
Makes a resigned, self-deprecating comment 'I suppose I would be too. But alas, I'm stuck with me.'
Sits on porch swing, focused on equations with pen in hand.
Jokes about 'being nuts' but having fun, showing self-awareness and humor despite struggles.
Appears pale and drawn, as if part of him is missing, indicating diminished vitality or mental sharpness.
Smiles actually when talking with Fox, seems sincerely puzzled when Fox says he missed him.
Slides his pad over to Fox to share his work, hoping to dazzle people to be reinstated.
Stares blankly at Fox when Fox suggests there are other things besides work; asks 'What are they?'
Asks Alicia what people do, showing a naive or childlike curiosity about ordinary life.
Smiles and jokes about taking out the garbage despite his heavy struggles.
Takes Alicia in his arms to comfort her when she is terrified.
Reassures Alicia by saying everything's going to be all right despite his own uncertainty.

Stands helplessly holding his crying baby, unable to soothe him or take effective action.
Takes Alicia in his arms to comfort her despite his own apparent uncertainty.
Struggles to write coherent equations, snaps his pencil in frustration.
Lies still and distances himself physically and emotionally from Alicia, explaining medication as a reason.
Holds his crying baby but appears unsure how to handle the situation, feeling helpless.
Pours the shards of Alicia's broken mirror into the trash quietly, helping clean up after a moment of emotional distress.
Smiles at Alicia despite her obvious pain and exhaustion, showing gentle acknowledgment.
Quietly contemplates his medication but chooses not to take the new pills, indicating personal struggle and possible avoidance.
Calls out into the night upon hearing a noise, showing concern or protectiveness about his environment or others.

Smiles and nods in response to Alicia despite both knowing they are lying about being fine.
Does not take his medication as prescribed, adding new pills to the drawer without swallowing any.
Notices unopened mail and unread math journals, implying neglect of responsibilities.
Responds quickly and alertly to a sound at the window, moving fast to investigate.
Chases after mysterious figure despite uncertainty, showing determination and engagement.
Responds cautiously and unsettled when confronted by Parcher, showing distrust.

Engages verbally with an apparently unreal figure, showing awareness of his mental state but remaining composed.
Holds Marcee tightly when she leaps into his arms.

Questions Parcher’s reality and trustworthiness firmly.

Stands silently as Alicia pushes him away and leaves with the baby, unable to speak or stop her.
Stares outside alone in the house after Alicia leaves, showing emotional vulnerability with trembling lips and tears.
Touches Alicia’s shoulder in the rain, sharing a quiet moment of connection despite conflict.
Stands silently, unable to respond when Alicia confronts him emotionally and pushes him away.
Remains standing alone in the doorway watching Alicia leave in the rain, showing emotional paralysis and indecision.

Manages a brave smile when facing Dr. Rosen.

Stops Alicia from coming closer out of concern for her safety.

Contemplates immersing himself in real life and people to escape his inner struggles.

Questions Milnor about their friendship, showing vulnerability and doubt.

Asks to be part of a community, aware it is a lot to ask, and anticipates rejection.
